Vapor-phase intramolecular aldol condensation of 2,5-hexanedione (2,5-HD) to 3-methyl-2-cyclopentenone (MCP) was performed over several rare-earth zirconate catalysts, with yttrium zirconate (YZrO) emerged as the most efficient catalyst. Several parameters, such as Y content, calcination temperature, reaction temperature, and contact time, highly influenced the catalytic performance of the YZrO catalyst: YZrO calcined at 700 °C exhibited the highest catalytic activity but still suffered from catalyst deactivation due to coke formation. Modifying the YZrO with Ag and employing the modified catalyst in an H2 flow effectively reduced the coke accumulation, thus improving the catalytic stability during the aldol condensation of 2,5-HD at 350 °C. The poisoning experiment with the co-fed of acidic CO2 gas and basic molecules of 2,6-, and 3,5-dimethylpyridine suggested that the aldol condensation proceeded via an acid-base concerted mechanism. Graphical Abstract Keywords Intramolecular aldol condensation 2,5-hexanedione Yttrium zirconate Deactivation control Data Availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction Mitigating the environmental impact of fossil fuel consumption has increasingly become imperative, considering that fossil fuels still become the major backbone for the production of numerous value-added chemicals [1–4]. Align with the rapid growth of society, the demand for value-added chemicals has been projected to increase exponentially [5]. The absence of a viable green and sustainable alternative will certainly increase the reliance on fossil fuels, thus raising the environmental impact [6]. Due to this reason, efficient and green alternatives for the production of value-added chemicals, which alleviate the consumption of fossil fuel, are highly desired [7]. The production of chemicals via catalytic transformation of biomass-derived compounds has been considered a promising alternative to reduce fossil fuel consumption [8]. The transformation of lignocellulosic biomass, in particular, offers sustainability since it is considered the most abundant carbon source [9,10]. The effort to boost the prospect of biomass transformation surely relies on highly efficient catalysts. Thus, the catalytic design that efficiently transforms biomass-derived compounds into value-added chemicals would be highly sought. Among numerous biomass-derived compounds, 2,5-hexanedione (2,5-HD) has received great interest due to its wide range of applications in the production of polymers, fine chemicals, solvents, and pharmaceuticals [11–13]. Recent reports have suggested that 2,5-HD can be obtained via cellulose hydrogenolysis [4,14,15]. The intramolecular aldol condensation of 2,5-HD has been reported to generate 3-methyl-2-cyclopentenone (MCP) ( Scheme 1), an important chemical for fuel additives [16,17]. Conventionally, basic catalysts such as NaOH and KOH can catalyze the aldol condensation of 2,5-HD to MCP [16]. Nevertheless, several issues, such as environmental concerns and the corrosive nature of those bases, have led to the search for more environmentally friendly catalysts [18]. Several solid base catalysts have been employed in liquid-phase aldol condensation of 2,5-HD to MCP [19]. Despite offering a high conversion of 2,5-HD, several Mg-based catalysts gave poor selectivity to MCP due to the formation of oligomer products. This issue is successfully overcome by employing a biphasic system, showing the potential of heterogeneous catalysis for converting 2,5-HD to MCP. Vapor-phase aldol condensation of 2,5-HD can also be viewed as a greener strategy for converting 2,5-HD to MCP than conventional protocol using homogeneous base catalysts. In this regard, we have reported that Li2O/ZrO2 and hydroxyapatite are highly active in the aldol condensation of 2,5-HD to MCP [20,21]. Introducing Li2O onto ZrO2 increases the basic sites while decreasing the acidity of the catalyst, leading to the generation of a highly active Li2O/ZrO2 catalyst. Similarly, the high efficiency of the hydroxyapatite in the aldol condensation of 2,5-HD is strongly influenced by its optimum acid and base nature. The importance of optimum acid-base properties is also found in the aldol condensation of methyl acetate with formaldehyde over Al2O3-supported Ba [22]. The generation of new base sites due to the addition of Ba onto Al2O3 support is responsible for the outstanding activity of the Al2O3-supported Ba catalyst. Referring to these reports, an efficient transformation of 2,5-HD to MCP can be realized over a catalyst with optimum acid and base properties. Previously, we have reported that yttrium zirconate (YZrO) catalysts, which contain acid and base sites, are highly efficient for the dehydration of 1,3-, 1,4-butanediol, and 3-methyl-1,3-butanediol [23–26]. The role of acid and base sites in the dehydration of butanediols has been elucidated by the poisoning experiment using CO2, 2,6-, and 3,5-dimethylpyridine (DMP), which further signify the prominent nature of acid and base properties of YZrO catalysts. Furthermore, the acid and base properties of the YZrO catalyst can be tuned by changing the Y/Zr ratio, calcination temperature, and preparation conditions [23–26]. Considering that the efficiency of the catalyst in the vapor-phase aldol condensation is highly correlated to the acid and base properties of the catalyst, YZrO could be considered as a potential candidate for the transformation of 2,5-HD to MCP. In this work, vapor-phase aldol condensation of 2,5-HD to MCP was conducted over a YZrO catalyst prepared via hydrothermal (HT) protocol. Several parameters, such as Y content, calcination temperature, reaction temperature, and contact time (W/F), influenced the catalytic activity of YZrO in the aldol condensation of 2,5-HD. Due to the catalyst deactivation, a modification of YZrO with Ag and the operation in H2 gas was conducted to reduce the coke accumulation, consecutively improving catalyst stability. The poisoning experiment using CO2, 2,6-, and 3,5-DMP signified the importance of acid and base sites of YZrO in the aldol condensation of 2,5-HD to MCP. Hence, it is plausible that the aldol condensation of 2,5-HD to MCP proceeds via an acid-base concerted mechanism. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation Zirconyl nitrate dihydrate (ZrO(NO3)2·2H 2O) with a commercial grade was available from Fujifilm Wako Chemicals, Co. Yttrium nitrate hexahydrate (Y(NO3)3·6H2O), gadolinium nitrate hexahydrate (Gd(NO3)3·6H2O), dysprosium nitrate hydrate (Dy(NO3)3·nH2O, where n was determined to be 7 by thermogravimetry (TG) analysis), holmium nitrate pentahydrate (Ho(NO3)3·5H2O), erbium nitrate pentahydrate (Er(NO3)3·5H2O), and ytterbium nitrate pentahydrate (Yb(NO3)3·5H2O) were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich, Co. The yttrium zirconate catalyst was prepared via an HT protocol, according to the previous literature [23,26]. Typically, a solution containing a desired amount of Zr4+ and Y3+ cations was prepared by dissolving ZrO(NO3)2·2H2O and Y(NO3)3·6H2O salts into 50 cm3 of H2O. Into the solution, a 10 cm3 aqueous solution of ammonia (25 wt%) was added dropwisely under vigorous stirring to form a white slurry. This slurry was hydrothermally treated at 200 °C for 24 h using a steel jacket. After the hydrothermal treatment, the white precipitate was washed with distilled water three times and dried at 110 °C for 15 h. The dried sample was calcined at a prescribed temperature for 3 h. The resulting catalyst was denoted as xYZrO-T, where x and T represented the Y content in mol% and calcination temperature in °C, respectively. The content of Y was changed by altering the amount of ZrO(NO3)2·2H2O and Y(NO3)3·6H2O salts. Other rare-earth metal zirconate (50REZrO) catalysts, such as 50GdZrO-700, 50DyZrO-700, 50HoZrO-700, 50ErZrO-700, and 50YbZrO-700, were prepared in a similar procedure. The 50YZrO-700-supported Ag catalyst was prepared via an impregnation protocol. A 10 cm3 aqueous solution of AgNO3 was added dropwisely onto 50YZrO-700. The water of the dropped solution was evaporated by illuminating the 50YZrO-700 with a 350 W bulb. After all the solution was added, the 50YZrO-700 containing Ag precursor was calcined at 400 °C for 3 h. The catalyst was denoted as yAg/50YZrO-700, where y was the Ag content in wt%. 2.2 Characterization The X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis was performed with New D8 ADVANCE (Bruker) using Cu Kα radiation (λ = 0.154 nm). The average crystallite size, D, was calculated using the Scherrer equation. The specific surface area, SA, of the catalyst was calculated from the N2 adsorption isotherm measured in a self-made gas adsorption apparatus at -196 °C using the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method. The average particle size, D p, was calculated from the SA with the following equation: D p = 6 d × SA where d is the density of Y2Zr2O7, d = 5.36 g cm-3 [23]. The high-resolution field emission scanning electron microscope (FE-SEM) image was observed on JSM-7100FA microscope (JEOL) operated at 15 kV. The TG analysis was performed using Thermoplus 8120E2 (Rigaku). After the sample had been heated at 110 °C for one hour to remove the physisorbed water, the weight change was recorded while the sample was heated in air from 110 to 900 °C at a heating rate of 5 °C min-1. The acid-base properties of the catalysts were investigated with temperature-programmed desorption of NH3 and CO2 gas (NH3- and CO2-TPD) using BELCATII (MicrotracBEL) equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). Prior to the analysis, the sample was pre-treated at 500 °C in a He flow for one hour. After the sample was cooled to 100 °C, a gas (either 5 wt% of NH3 or CO2 in N2) was introduced to the sample for one hour. The desorption of the NH3 or CO2 gas was monitored while the sample was heated in a He flow from 100 to 800 °C with a heating rate of 10 °C min-1. We also performed a blank TPD experiment for the sample under the same pretreatment without adsorption of probe gas because the TCD can detect gases such as water and oxygen desorbed from the catalyst. Fig. S1 (A–C) shows the blank TCD signal profile as a function of temperature as well as the original TCD signals of adsorbed NH3 and CO2. A difference TCD signal between the NH3 adsorption and the blank signal was converted to a NH3-TPD profile using molar sensitivity of NH3. In a similar way, the CO2-TPD profile was obtained from the difference TCD signal between CO2 adsorption and the blank one. The amounts of acid and base sites were estimated from the integral of the desorption profiles of NH3 and CO2, respectively [23]. To identify the components of gases produced thermally from an as-prepared catalyst sample, the temperature-programmed decomposition with mass spectrometer (TD-MS) profile was recorded on a BELCATII with a BELLMASS unit (MicrotracBEL): a sample (ca. 50 mg) was heated in an He flow from 100 to 800 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C min-1. The produced gases were monitored using a TCD and a quadrupole mass analyzer. 2.3 Catalytic test The vapor-phase intramolecular aldol condensation of 2,5-HD was performed in a fixed-bed down-flow glass tube reactor. The catalyst with a weight (W) of typically 0.5 g was loaded into the reactor tube and preheated in a 30 cm3 min-1 of N2 or H2 flow at a reaction temperature for one hour. 2,5-HD was fed into the reactor at a liquid feed rate (F) = 1.80 g h-1, together with carrier gas. The contact time (W/F) represents the time taken for the fed reactant to reach the same weight as the catalyst. Under the typical conditions, where W = 0.5 g and F = 1.8 g h-1, the W/F = 0.28 h. The catalytic reaction was performed at a temperature between 250 and 350 °C for a time on stream (TOS) of 5 or 13 h. The liquid effluents were recovered periodically every hour. The recovered products were identified using a gas chromatograph (GC) equipped with a mass-spectrometer (QP5050A, Shimadzu) and a capillary column (Inert Cap WAX-HT, a length of 30 m, an inner diameter of 0.32 mm, GL-Sciences). The liquid effluents collected in a dry ice-acetone trap at –78 °C were quantitatively analyzed by GC equipped with a flame ionization detector (GC-14B, Shimadzu) with a 60-m capillary column (Inert Cap 1 with an inner diameter of 0.25 mm, GL-Sciences). In the poisoning experiment of the acid sites, 2,5-HD was co-fed with either 5 wt% of 2,6- or 3,5-DMP. Meanwhile, the poisoning experiment of the base sites was conducted by introducing 1.5 cm3 min-1 of CO2 gas into the carrier gas while keeping the total flow rate at 30 cm3 min-1. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalysts screening Previously, we have employed sixteen 50REZrO-900 catalysts in the dehydration of several diols, such as 1,3- and 1,4-butanediol, and 3-methyl-1,3-butanediol [23–26]. Fig. S2 clearly shows that zirconates of Yb, Er, Dy, Gd, and Y give higher conversion than other 50REZrO-900 catalysts in the dehydration of 1,4-butanediol [23]. Although it is not clear which character of catalyst regulates the activity, it is worth noting that these zirconates also show remarkable activity in the dehydration of 3-methyl-1,3-butanediol [26]. Thus, it is interesting to investigate the performance of these zirconates in the aldol condensation of 2,5-HD. Fig. 1 shows the time course profiles of several 50REZrO-700 of Yb, Er, Dy, Gd, Y, and Ho in this aldol condensation of 2,5-HD to MCP at 300 °C and a W/F of 0.28 h. The numerical data for the catalytic activity, as well as their respective SA, are summarized in Table S1. All the 50REZrO-700 catalysts tested gave remarkable MCP selectivity (>95 %, except 50GdZrO-700); nevertheless, the 50YZrO-700 catalyst with the largest SA of 79 m2 g-1 gave a higher conversion of 2,5-HD than other catalysts tested. The efficiency of the 50YZrO catalyst in the butanediol dehydration is driven by the optimum crystallite size and acid-base properties of the 50YZrO catalyst [23–25]. It is reasonable to assume that similar properties are also responsible for the efficiency of the 50YZrO-700 catalyst in the aldol condensation of 2,5-HD, considering that aldol condensation of 2,5-HD also proceeds via an acid-base concerted mechanism [21]. 3.2 Effect of Y content Fig. 2 shows the XRD pattern of xYZrO-700 catalysts with different Y contents. The change in the Y content affected the crystal structure of the xYZrO-700 catalysts. In the absence of Y, the crystal structure of ZrO2 was monoclinic. The addition of 10 and 20 mol% Y into the ZrO2 matrix changed the crystal structure of the catalyst from monoclinic to tetragonal. The increment of Y content from 20 to 30 mol% changed the crystal structure from tetragonal to cubic fluorite, and this cubic fluorite structure was maintained up to the Y content of 50 mol%. The xYZrO-700 catalysts with a Y content of 60 mol% or above had the crystal structure of cubic bixbyite Y2O3 together with a shoulder peak of cubic fluorite. A similar transformation of the YZrO crystal phase due to different Y content at a high calcination temperature of 900 °C has been reported previously [25]. It has also been reported that the structural transformation from monoclinic to cubic occurs due to ZrO2 lattice distortion [27,28], and this is a strong indication that Y2O3 has been successfully incorporated into the ZrO2 lattice [29]. We also examined the correlation between the Y fraction and the lattice parameter, a, of xYZrO-700 catalysts in the x range between 30 and 100 mol%, where the samples show the same cubic crystal structure. We excluded the 10YZrO-700 and 20YZrO-700 with tetragonal structure. Fig. S3 shows a correlation between a and Y content in the x range from 30 to 60 mol%, where the lattice parameter of bixbyite, a’, (x = 60 – 100 mol%) is double of a of fluorite (x = 30 – 50 mol%) due to the difference in the size of the unit cell (a’ = 2a). A linear correlation between a and Y content in the x range from 40 to 60 mol% suggests the incorporation of Y into the ZrO2 lattice. Above 60 mol% of Y, however, a’ was constant, indicating that Zr was hardly incorporated in the bixbyite Y2O3 structure. Thus, the 75YZrO could be a mixture of Y2O3 and Y2Zr2O7. These results suggest that even though the HT protocol could facilitate the incorporation of Y2O3 species into the ZrO2 lattice, the amount of Y fraction needs to be considered. It has been reported that the efficient incorporation of Y2O3 into the ZrO2 lattice was due to the homogenization of Y3+ and Zr4+ species during HT protocol [29]. In the following catalysis, this phenomenon is highly beneficial since xYZrO-700, with a homogeneous distribution of Y3+ and Zr4+ species, could provide a homogeneous distribution of active sites. Fig. 3A shows the correlation between Y content, D, and SA of the xYZrO-700 catalysts. The increment of Y content to 60 mol% increased the SA of the xYZrO-700 catalysts, and a further increment of Y content to 100 mol% decreased the SA of the catalysts. A similar enlargement of SA of the YZrO catalyst due to the incorporation of Y into the ZrO2 crystal lattice has also been reported [25,28,30]. The extent of the increment of the SA due to the incorporation of Y varies since several YZrO catalysts were prepared using different methods. Nevertheless, the enlargement of the SA due to the incorporation of Y into the ZrO2 lattice has been well-established in the yttrium-stabilized zirconia system. The enlargement of the SA of zirconia has also been found in the zirconia-incorporated SiO2 [31]. It has been suggested that the addition of SiO2 into the ZrO2 matrix inhibits the diffusion of ZrO2, hindering the nucleation of the ZrO2 crystallites [31]. Since the incorporation of Y into the ZrO2 lattice was also observed in the YZrO-700 catalyst, a similar effect of nucleation hindrance might also occur. As a result, the aggregation of the xYZrO-700 crystallites was inhibited, leading to the formation of smaller xYZrO-700 crystallites, i.e., larger SA. This assumption is corroborated by the change in the D with Y content (Fig. 3A). It can be said that the incorporation of Y up to 50 and 60 mol% into ZrO2 lattice efficiency hinders the aggregation of ZrO2 crystallites, leading to the formation of the xYZrO-700 with the largest SA. Upon further addition of Y content, the cubic bixbyite phase of Y2O3 and its nucleation might have become more dominant, leading to the generation of xYZrO-700 catalyst with smaller SA. Fig. 3B shows the FE-SEM image of 50YZrO-700. The SEM image clearly shows that the sample calcined at 700 °C is composed of agglomerates of particles with a size of 10–20 nm. The size of particles is consistent with the average particle size (D p = 14 nm) calculated using the finding from the SA of 79 m2 g-1 (Table S2). Since the particle size observed in the SEM image and the D p calculated from the SA of 50YZrO-700 catalyst are obviously larger than the average crystallite size, D, calculated using the Scherrer equation (D = 5.0 nm), a particle of 50YZrO-700 is considered as aggregated crystallites. This result is consistent with the previous work of YZrO calcined at different temperatures [31]. The close values between the observed particle size in the SEM image and the calculated D p from SA indicate that the particles shown in the SEM image are non-porous primary particles. Fig. 3C shows the effect of Y content on the catalytic activity of xYZrO-700 catalysts, while the change in conversion with TOS is displayed in Fig. S4. The effect of Y content on the SA and the catalytic activity of xYZrO-700 catalysts was nearly identical. It can be said that the change in SA of the xYZrO-700 catalysts due to the increment of Y content might have also influenced the catalytic activity of the respective catalyst. The MCP selectivity exceeded 94 mol% over all the xYZrO-700 catalysts except ZrO2, indicating that the YZrO catalyst did not favor any side reactions, regardless of the Y content. The superiority of 50YZrO-700–60YZrO-700 was possibly related to the difference in crystal phase. Previously, we have reported that cubic fluorite structure generates better adsorption sites than cubic bixbyite in the dehydration of 1,4-butanediol despite having less oxygen vacancy [25]. This behavior originates from the different positions of the oxygen vacancies. In a cubic fluorite structure, the isolated oxygen vacancies are randomly located and overall cover 1/8 of surface oxygens. Meanwhile, the cubic bixbyite structure has clusters of oxygen vacancies, which form a three-rayed structure and overall cover only 1/16 of surface oxygens. Thus, it is understandable that 50YZrO-700, with a cubic fluorite structure, gave a better catalytic performance than 60YZrO-700, which has a cubic bixbyite structure. 3.3 Effect of calcination temperature Fig. 4 illustrates the effect of the calcination temperature of 50YZrO catalysts on their SA. The increase in calcination temperature decreased the SA of 50YZrO catalysts due to the aggregation of cubic Y2Zr2O7 crystallites. These findings well agree with our previous report, where the increase in calcination temperature clearly increases the crystallite size of the 50YZrO samples [23]. Fig. 4 also shows that the calcination temperature significantly affects the catalytic activity of 50YZrO-T catalysts. The change in conversion of 2,5-HD with TOS for each 50YZrO-T catalyst in this report is depicted in Fig. S5. The increment of calcination temperature from 500 to 700 °C increased the catalytic activity of the 50YZrO-T catalysts even though the SA of the 50YZrO-T clearly decreased. However, a further increment of calcination temperature from 700 to 900 °C decreased the catalytic activity of 50YZrO-T catalysts, following the trend of the SA of the 50YZrO-T. Previously, we have reported that the change in calcination temperature up to 1050 °C intensifies the peaks associated with the cubic fluorite structure but does not change the crystal structure of cubic Y2Zr2O7 [23]. These findings suggest that the change in the catalytic performance of the 50YZrO-T catalysts due to the change in calcination temperature was not caused by the change in the crystal structure. In addition, the catalytic performance of the 50YZrO-T catalysts was not solely affected by the SA. This issue will be discussed in the following section, which is related to the residual carbonate observed in the results of TD-MS. Fig. 5A and B reveal the NH3- and CO2-TPD of 50YZrO-500 and 50YZrO-700 catalysts, and the amount of acid and base sites are shown in Table 1. Similar to the previous report on the yttria-stabilized zirconia [32], the increase in the calcination temperature decreased the amount of acid and base sites of the 50YZrO-T catalysts. Since the increment of calcination temperature also decreased the SA of the 50YZrO-T catalysts, it is understandable that the amount of acid and base sites decreases with the increase in calcination temperature. This assumption is further substantiated by the fact that the acid and base density of the unmodified 50YZrO and 1Ag/50-YZrO catalysts are nearly identical. In the TD-MS profile (Fig. S1D), 50YZrO-500 had a CO2 peak (m/z = 44) at 500 – 800 °C, which could originate from the carbonate species in the as-prepared 50YZrO sample. This assumption is further supported by the TG profiles of the as-prepared sample which reveals that the weight change has not been completed at 500 °C [26]. Additionally, the TD-MS profiles of the 50YZrO-300 still had residual nitrate, NO3, species observed at m/z = 14, 30, and 32 (Fig. S6) along with residual carbonate. This result strongly highlights that a low calcination temperature is not enough to remove the residual species in the as-prepared 50YZrO sample, which can potentially affect the catalytic activity of the resulting catalyst. In contrast to the 50YZrO calcined at low temperatures (Figs. S1D and S4), the residual peaks in the 50YZrO-700 were hardly visible (Fig. S1E). Furthermore, the weight change of the as-prepared 50YZrO sample has been completed at 700 °C, as indicated by the TG profiles [26]. These findings suggest that the calcination at 700 °C has completely decomposed the residual species in the as-prepared 50YZrO sample. It can be assumed that the desorption signal at high temperatures (550 – 800 °C) in the 50YZrO-500 catalyst (Fig. 5A) might not originate from the NH3 or CO2 gas desorbed during TPD measurement, but rather from the decomposition of the carbonate species. Due to this issue, it is challenging to clearly correlate the acid and base amounts of the catalyst calcined at different temperatures with their respective activities. The calcination temperature affects the activity of the 50YZrO-T catalyst by affecting the residual carbonate species as well as SA, acid-base ratio, and crystallite size. Even though the calcination temperature of 500 °C generated a 50YZrO catalyst with the highest amount of acid and base as well as the largest SA, the presence of residual carbonate and small crystallite size would not be conducive for efficient aldol condensation of 2,5-HD. On the other hand, the high calcination temperature of 900 °C generated a 50YZrO catalyst with small SA and acid-base amount despite facilitating efficient conditions for removing the residual species in the as-prepared 50YZrO sample. It can be concluded that the calcination temperature at 700 °C can generate a 50YZrO catalyst with optimum crystallinity and reasonable SA for efficient aldol condensation of 2,5-HD. 3.4 Effect of reaction conditions, such as temperature and W/F Fig. 6A reveals the effect of reaction temperatures on the catalytic activity of the 50YZrO-700 catalyst at a W/F of 0.28 h. The conversion of 2,5-HD increases as the temperature increases from 250 to 300 °C. Nevertheless, a further increment of reaction temperature to 350 °C decreases the conversion of 2,5-HD. The time course of the 50YZrO-700 catalyst at reaction temperatures of 300, 325, and 350 °C shows that the decrement of the average conversion of 2,5-HD was due to the severe catalyst deactivation (Fig. S7A). Notably, high reaction temperatures also increased the rate of a side reaction since the MCP selectivity decreased. Fig. 6B illustrates the effect of W/F on the catalytic activity of the 50YZrO-700 catalyst at 300 °C. The change in conversion with TOS for each W/F is displayed in Fig. S7B. Prolonging the W/F increased the catalytic activity of the 50YZrO-700 catalyst. The MCP selectivity was not significantly affected by the change in W/F, indicating that the increase in catalyst amount did not promote any side reaction. It is worth noting that prolonging W/F, i.e., increasing catalyst amount affected the average MCP productivity (P MCP) in the initial 5 h of the aldol condensation of 2,5-HD. Fig. 6B clearly shows that prolonging the W/F from 0.17 to 0.28 h increases the P MCP, and the highest P MCP is 0.98 g gcat -1 h-1 at 300 °C; nevertheless, further increment of W/F declines the P MCP. This result suggests that the efficiency of the 50YZrO-700 to produce MCP decreases when an excessive amount of catalyst is employed. 3.5 Deactivation control: 50YZrO-modified Ag under a flow of hydrogen gas The time-course profiles in Figs. 1, S3, S4, and S6 show that despite being active in the aldol condensation of 2,5-HD, the 50YZrO-700 catalyst was deactivated regardless of the reaction conditions. Previously, we have reported that the Ag-H2 modification successfully improves the stability of hydroxyapatite and TiO2 catalysts in the aldol condensation [21,33]. In addition, the same strategy has also been effective in improving the catalyst stability in the acid-catalyzed dehydration [34]. Referring to these works, the effort to improve the stability of 50YZrO-700 was conducted using the Ag-H2 modification. The efficiency of the Ag loading on the surface of 50YZrO-700 was examined by performing the experiment in an H2 flow. Fig. 7A summarizes the effect of Ag content on the catalytic activity of the 50YZrO-700 catalysts at 300 °C and a W/F of 0.28 h under a flow of H2. The modification of Ag-H2 successfully improved the catalytic activity of the 50YZrO-700 catalyst, owing to the improvement of catalyst stability as indicated in Fig. 7B. The Ag loading up to 1 wt% improved the 50YZrO-700 stability; however, excessive Ag content was proven less effective in preventing catalyst deactivation. The XRD result in Fig. S8 reveals that the Ag loading on the 50YZrO-700 catalyst did not substantially alter the structure of the 50YZrO-700. The peak associated with Ag species was hardly visible, due to a low Ag content present on 50YZrO-700. Even though the structure of 50YZrO-700 did not change, the acid amount increased after the addition of Ag (Fig. 5C and Table 1). The TD-MS profiles of the as-prepared 1Ag/50YZrO-700 catalyst (Fig. S1F) reveal that residual NO3 species (NO, m/z = 30) in the Ag precursor have been removed after the calcination at 400 °C. Therefore, the increment of acid site amount does not originate from the residual Ag precursor but from the probe molecules adsorbed on the Ag species supported on 50YZrO-700. Figs. 7A and 7B have indicated the importance of Ag in improving the stability of the 50YZrO-700 catalyst. To further verify the importance of H2 gas in improving the catalytic stability of the 50YZrO-700 catalyst, the catalytic activity of both 50YZrO-700 and 1Ag/50YZrO-700 catalysts were compared under a flow of N2 and H2 gases (Fig. S9). The 1Ag/50YZrO-700 catalyst was still deactivated in N2 gas, suggesting that the absence of H2 gas still led to catalyst deactivation despite the presence of Ag. These results strongly imply that the combination of Ag and H2 was essential in ensuring the stability of the 50YZrO-700 catalyst during aldol condensation of 2,5-HD. Fig. 7C compares the amount of coke deposited on the spent 50YZrO-700 and 1Ag/50YZrO-700 catalysts. The amount of coke deposited on 1Ag/50YZrO-700 was substantially smaller than that on the 50YZrO-700 catalyst. Fig. S8 illustrates the XRD patterns of the spent yAg/50YZrO-700 catalysts with different Ag content. The intensity of the peak associated with Y2Zr2O7 species in the spent 50YZrO-700 and 3Ag/50YZrO-700 catalysts decreased compared to the fresh ones. A substantial decrement in the peak intensity was clearly visible for the spent catalyst with the highest coke accumulation. On the other hand, the decrement in peak intensity was smaller in the 1Ag/50YZrO-700 catalyst. This finding suggests that coke deposition on the catalyst was the source of catalyst deactivation; thus, the inhibition of the coke formation by Ag-H2 modification significantly improves catalyst stability in the aldol condensation. Fig. 7D reveals the effect of reaction temperature on the catalytic activity of the 1Ag/50YZrO-700 at a W/F of 0.28 h. In contrast to the unmodified 50YZrO-700 catalysts (Figs. 6A and S7A), the catalytic activity of the 1Ag/50YZrO-700 catalyst increased with the increase in reaction temperature. Fig. 8 depicts the prolonged TOS of the 1Ag/50YZrO-700 catalyst at 350 °C at a W/F of 0.28 h. In an H2 flow, a gradual decrement of catalytic activity of 1Ag/50YZrO-700 catalyst from 100 % to 76 % was observed within 13 h of TOS, signifying the improvement of catalytic stability. On the other hand, the catalytic activity of the unmodified 50YZrO-700 catalyst significantly declined from 78 % to 14 % within a TOS of 5 h in an N2 flow. Changing the carrier gas to H2 declined the activity of the unmodified 50YZrO-700 even further (Fig. S9). This comparison further substantiates the efficiency of the Ag-H2 modification to inhibit coke formation, which is essential in improving the stability of the 50YZrO-700 catalyst. It is worth noting that the utilization of the Ag-H2 strategy did not reduce the MCP selectivity (Fig. 8). The hydrogenation products, such as 2,5-hexanediol, 3-methylcyclopent-2-en-1-ol, or 3-methyl-cyclopentan-1-one were not observed due to a low hydrogenation ability of Ag metal [35]. The P MCP in the aldol condensation of 2,5-HD using 1Ag/50YZrO-700 catalyst at 350 °C and W/F of 0.28 h is 3.1 and 2.6 g gcat -1 h-1 at a TOS of 5 and 13 h, respectively. In contrast, the P MCP of 50YZrO-700 catalyst under the same reaction condition is only 0.47 g gcat -1 h-1 at a TOS of 5 h. These results demonstrate the efficiency of the Ag-H2 method in improving the activity of 50YZrO-700 catalyst for aldol condensation of 2,5-HD. The catalytic performance of the 1Ag/50YZrO-700 catalyst in the vapor-phase system is comparable to several catalysts reported in the liquid-phase system (Table S3). Obviously, the reaction temperature in the vapor phase is substantially higher than that in the liquid phase due to the high boiling point of 2,5-HD. Nevertheless, the MCP selectivity in our work remains high since 1Ag/50YZrO-700 did not facilitate a substantial side reaction even at high reaction temperatures. 3.6 Poisoning experiment: The role of acid and base sites in the 50YZrO-700 catalyst The role of acid and base sites of 50YZrO-700 and 1Ag/50YZrO-700 catalysts was investigated with poisoning experiments using CO2, 2,6-, and 3,5-DMP. As an acidic gas, CO2 poisons the catalyst by hindering the adsorption of 2,5-HD on base sites. Meanwhile, 2,6- and 3,5-DMP inhibit the adsorption of 2,5-HD on acid sites of the catalyst. More specifically, 2,6-DMP has been reported to poison the Brønsted acid sites (BAS), but the existence of two methyl groups around the N atom inhibits the adsorption of 2,6-DMP on the Lewis acid sites (LAS) [36,37]. In contrast, 3,5-DMP with two methyl groups away from the N atom has been reported to poison both the BAS and LAS [36,37]. Due to this nature of DMPs, the decline in the catalytic activity of 50YZrO-700 and 1Ag/50YZrO-700 catalysts in the presence of CO2, 2,6-, and 3,5-DMP could reveal the importance of the acid and base sites of the catalysts. Fig. 9A illustrates the effect of the poisoning experiment using CO2, 2,6-, and 3,5-DMP on the catalytic activity of 50YZrO-700 at 300 °C and W/F of 0.28 h in an N2 flow. The conversion of 2,5-HD decreased in the presence of CO2, indicating that the hindrance to the base sites decreased the catalytic activity of the 50YZrO-700 catalyst. The hindrance to BAS and LAS by 2,6- and 3,5-DMP poisoning also decreased the catalytic activity of 50YZrO-700. These results indicate that base sites, LAS, and BAS of 50YZrO-700 were important for aldol condensation of 2,5-HD to MCP. Fig. 9B summarizes the poisoning experiment on the 1Ag/50YZrO-700 catalyst at 300 °C and a W/F of 0.28 h. A flow of H2 gas was used for the poisoning experiment since the 1Ag/50YZrO-700 catalyst performed well in H2 gas. Similar to the unmodified 50YZrO-700 catalyst, the hindrance to the base sites reduced the activity of the 1Ag/50YZrO-700 catalyst. However, the contribution of BAS in the 1Ag/50YZrO-700 catalyst was negligible since there is no substantial decrement of catalytic activity in the presence of 2,6-DMP. Meanwhile, a notable decline in the catalytic activity was observed in the reaction in the presence of 3,5-DMP. These results demonstrate that the LAS of 1Ag/50YZrO-700 catalyst was essential for the aldol condensation even in an H2 flow. Thus, the conversion of 2,5-HD to MCP over the 1Ag/50YZrO-700 catalyst in an H2 flow proceeded over its base and Lewis acid sites. Previously, we have proposed a speculative reaction mechanism of intramolecular aldol condensation of 2,5-HD to MCP over a hydroxyapatite catalyst [21,33]. The co-existence of NH3 and CO2 gas declined the catalytic activity of the hydroxyapatite catalyst, implying that the aldol condensation takes place on the acid and base sites of the catalyst. In this study, we can also claim that the formation of MCP from 2,5-HD over the 1Ag/50YZrO-700 catalyst proceeds via a LAS-base concerted mechanism. Even though it is well known that aldol condensation is catalyzed by basic catalysts, several reports have shown that aldol condensation also proceeds over catalysts containing both acid and base sites [21,33,38–42]. The Rietveld analysis has suggested that 50YZrO has an oxygen-deficient cubic fluorite structure, where oxygen defects arbitrarily exist on the surface [23]. The oxygen defect exposes the LAS of Y3+ and Zr4+ with the surrounding Lewis base of O2 - to act as the adsorption site of butanediols [24,25]. In the dehydration of butanediols over 50YZrO, the Zr4+ and Y3+ anchor the alcohol on its OH group, while the basic O2 - abstracts the proton from the alcohol [24,25]. In the aldol condensation of methyl acetate and formaldehyde, Wang et al. have also suggested that the C=O of methyl acetate and formaldehyde are attached to the LAS, while the basic O2 - is responsible to abstract the proton from methyl acetate [41]. It can be assumed that the role of LAS of Y3+ and Zr4+ and base sites of O2 - in the aldol condensation of 2,5-HD is identical to that of these reports. Furthermore, the poisoning experiment in Fig. 9 clearly corroborates the importance of LAS and base sites. Scheme 2 illustrates the speculative mechanism of the aldol condensation of 2,5-HD to MCP. In this work, it is reasonable to assume that the LAS could anchor the 2,5-HD on its C=O group, while the base sites of O2 - abstract the proton from 2,5-HD, generating an enolate ion. The enolate could attack the neighboring C=O to generate cyclic aldol. Following the dehydration of cyclic aldol, MCP and water are generated. In summary, the 50YZrO-700 catalyst was proven efficient for the vapor-phase aldol condensation of 2,5-HD to MCP. Although the catalyst was deactivated with TOS, this issue was effectively addressed by the Ag-H2 method. This work highlights a promising strategy for MCP formation originating from biomass-derived 2,5-HD, which strongly aligns with the grand scheme of biomass valorization. 4 Conclusion Vapor-phase aldol condensation of 2,5-HD to MCP was conducted over the xYZrO-T catalysts. Several parameters, such as Y content, calcination temperature, reaction temperature, and W/F, affected the catalytic activity of the xYZrO-T catalysts. The Y content affected the activity of the xYZrO-700 catalysts by influencing SA and the crystal structure of the xYZrO-700 catalysts. While the calcination temperature mainly affected the residual carbonate species as well as the SA of the 50YZrO catalyst. Optimum reaction temperature and W/F were necessary to ensure high activity, selectivity, and MCP productivity. The stability of the 50YZrO-700 catalyst was substantially improved by the Ag-H2 modification, owing to the inhibition of coke formation. Lastly, the poisoning experiment using CO2, 2,6-, and 3,5-DMP implies that the aldol condensation proceeds via an acid-base concerted mechanism. coredata.dc:description: Vapor-phase intramolecular aldol condensation of 2,5-hexanedione (2,5-HD) to 3-methyl-2-cyclopentenone (MCP) was performed over several rare-earth zirconate catalysts, with yttrium zirconate (YZrO) emerged as the most efficient catalyst. Several parameters, such as Y content, calcination temperature, reaction temperature, and contact time, highly influenced the catalytic performance of the YZrO catalyst: YZrO calcined at 700 °C exhibited the highest catalytic activity but still suffered from catalyst deactivation due to coke formation. Modifying the YZrO with Ag and employing the modified catalyst in an H2 flow effectively reduced the coke accumulation, thus improving the catalytic stability during the aldol condensation of 2,5-HD at 350 °C. The poisoning experiment with the co-fed of acidic CO2 gas and basic molecules of 2,6-, and 3,5-dimethylpyridine suggested that the aldol condensation proceeded via an acid-base concerted mechanism.
